metadata.title: Electrophoretic deposition (EPD) of nano-hydroxyapatite coatings with improved mechanical properties on prosthetic Ti6Al4V substrates

sections.text:
Surface & Coatings Technology xxx (2015) xxx–xxx
SCT-20814; No of Pages 6
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Surface & Coatings Technology
j ourna l homepage: www.e lsev ie r .com/ locate /sur fcoat
Electrophoretic deposition (EPD) of nano-hydroxyapatite coatings with improved mechanical properties on prosthetic Ti6Al4V substrates
R. Drevet a,⁎, N. Ben Jaber a,b, J. Fauré a, A. Tara a, A. Ben Cheikh Larbi b, H. Benhayoune a a Université de Reims Champagne-Ardenne, LISM EA 4695, 21 rue Clément ADER, 51685, Reims BP 138 Cedex 02, France b Université de Tunis, LMMP, 5 Av. Taha HUSSIN Monfleury, 1008 Tunis, Tunisia
⁎ Corresponding author. E-mail addresses: richard.drevet@univ-reims.fr, richar
http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.surfcoat.2015.12.058 0257-8972/© 2015 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
Please cite this article as: R. Drevet, et al., Su
a b s t r a c t a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 29 October 2015 Revised 16 December 2015 Accepted in revised form 18 December 2015 Available online xxxx
This work aims at studying the synthesis of hydroxyapatite (HAP) coatings by electrophoretic deposition (EPD) of a nano-sized powder. In this research, the variation of the potential and the deposition time, two essential experimental parameters, is explored. It has been established by scanning electron microscopy combined with energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (SEM–EDXS) and X-ray diffraction (XRD) that the best results are obtained for deposition of the coating at 10V during 10min. Subsequently, the electrophoretic depositionwas followed by thermal treatment of the samples in a controlled atmosphere to enhance their mechanical properties (hardness and Young's Modulus), key parameters to improve the lifespan of the implant materials. In this way, an innovative synthesis process has been developed to produce nano-HAP coatings with appropriate dimensional features known to provide an improved biological response.
© 2015 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved. Keywords: Electrophoretic deposition Hydroxyapatite coating Nanometer feature size SEM XRD Nanoindentation

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Most of the implant materials used in orthopedic surgery are made of titanium or its alloys well-known for their appropriate mechanical properties required to replace the bone in vivo [1]. However, their capability to adhere to bone tissue is unsatisfactory and may result in wear debris that can lead to inflammatory reactions [2]. Thus, in order to improve osseointegration and biocompatibility of medical implants, the titanium alloys are commonly coated with hydroxyapatite (HAP), a bioceramic material with a chemical composition close to that of the bone. Consequently, the implant is able to establish a direct chemical bondwith the surrounding bone tissue, resulting in increased lifespan inside the body [3,4]. Various techniques were developed to produce hydroxyapatite coatings such as plasma spraying [5], magnetron RF-sputtering [6], micro-arc oxidation [7], electrophoretic deposition [8], and many other techniques. Among them, electrophoretic deposition is a technique that consists in the migration of bioceramic powder particles in suspension under the effect of an electric field. Therefore, the particles agglomerate and form the coating at the surface of the implant used as an electrode [9]. A very interesting aspect of this technique is the possibility
ddrevet@yahoo.fr (R. Drevet). Fig. 1. Sketch of the electrophoretic deposition process.
rf. Coat. Technol. (2015), http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.surfcoat.2015.12.058
Fig. 2.nano-HAP coating obtained in10min. by EPD at (a) 5V, (b) 10V, (c) 15V and (d) 20V. Fig. 4.nano-HAP coating obtained at 10V by EPD in (a) 5min., (b) 10min., (c) 15min. and (d) 20 min.
to carry out the deposition of hydroxyapatite coatings from nano-sized powders, in contrast to other deposition techniques that generally produce coatings with micrometric features. In particular, several research groups have established that nano-metric surface featuresmay bemore desirable as they impact positively the response of osteoblasts owing to the importance of nanoscale interactions during cellular recognition of biomolecules, organization of the extracellular matrix, hierarchical structure of tissues, etc. [10]. As a result, it may be more advantageous to engineer surfaces with nanoscale features as a way to further enhance the osteoinduction, osteoconduction, and osseointegration of the HAP coating deposited on the titanium alloy implant [11,12]. Moreover, as the process is carried out inside a liquid medium, it requires after deposition a thermal treatment to evaporate the solvent trapped within the nano-HAP coating and to improve its mechanical properties. This thermal treatment has to be carried out in a controlled atmosphere to prevent any alteration of the titanium alloy substrate as we demonstrated in recent work [13]. In conclusion, the present work aims at producing, for the first time, a nano-HAP coatingwith enhanced mechanical properties by electrophoretic deposition.
Please cite this article as: R. Drevet, et al., Surf. Coat. Technol. (2015), http

sections.heading: 2.1. Electrophoretic deposition (EPD)
sections.text:
Electrophoretic deposition (EPD) was carried out in a suspension prepared by dispersing 2 g of HAP nano-powder in 25 mL of ethanol. The commercial nano-powder (Aldrich) had a particle size below 200 nm. The suspension of HAP was obtained by ultrasonic dispersion (50 kHz) for 40 min. The particles became positively charged in contact with ethanol, and therefore cathodic EPD was performed (Fig. 1) [14].
Two Ti6Al4V disks (12mmin diameter and 4mmin thickness)were used as metallic electrodes. They were cleaned by ultrasonication with acetone and then with water prior to deposition. The distance between the two metallic electrodes was set at 20 mm. The Ti6Al4V disk positioned at the cathode to receive the coating had a surface roughness of 2 μm, produced by grit-blasting with alumina. EPD was performed at room temperature. Various voltage and deposition timeswere tested. Finally, the as-deposited coatings were air dried at room temperature for 24 h.
D at (a) 5 V, (b) 10 V, (c) 15 V and (d) 20 V. (The insets show highmagnification images.)
://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.surfcoat.2015.12.058
Fig. 5. SEMmicrograph at lowmagnification of the nano-HAP coating obtained at 10 V by EPD in (a) 5 min., (b) 10min., (c) 15min. and (d) 20 min. (The insets show highmagnification images.)

sections.heading: 2.2. Thermal treatment under controlled atmosphere
sections.text:
The coated Ti6Al4Vdiskswere thermally treated in a tubular furnace (Nabertherm RS 80/500/11) according to the specific protocol developed in previous work [13]. Initially, a secondary vacuum of about 10−5mbarwas achieved into theworking tubewith a pumping system. Then, a continuous flow of argonmaintained at 100 L·h−1 was injected into the working tube, resulting in an increase of the pressure to about 10−2 mbar. Finally, the temperature was raised in two steps according to the protocol proposed by Vallet-Regi and Gonzalez-Calbet [15]: a first plateau at 120 °C during 1 h for evaporation of water, followed by a second plateau at 1.000 °C during 1 h. The flow of argon was maintained throughout the entire thermal treatment until the complete cooling to room temperature.
2.3. Scanning electronmicroscopy and energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (SEM–EDXS)
The morphology of the coatings surface was observed using a LaB6 scanning electron microscope (JEOL JSM 6460 LV) operating at 0–30 kV, in conjunction with an ultra-thin window Si(Li) detector
Please cite this article as: R. Drevet, et al., Surf. Coat. Technol. (2015), http
used for energy-dispersive X-ray analysis. The X-ray spectra were acquired at primary beam energy of 15 keV with an acquisition time of 100 s. For quantitative analyses (Ca/P atomic ratio), commercial software (PGT, France) was used, adapted to a procedure previously developed in our laboratory for the coating analysis [16].
2.4. X-ray diffraction (XRD)
The phase composition of the samples was investigated using an X-ray diffractometer (Bruker D8 Advance). The X-ray data were collected between 10° to 60° (2Ө) with a step of 0.06° every 8 s, using monochromatic CuKa radiation. XRD analysis was carried out before and after the thermal treatment. Phase identification was performed using the Powder Diffraction Files (PDFs) of the International Center for Diffraction Data (ICDD).
2.5. Mechanical study
2.5.1. Nanoindentation Nanoindentation tests were performed with the Nanoindenter XP (CSM Instruments), using a Berkovich three-sided pyramidal diamond
nano-HAP coating obtained by EPD at 10 V in 10 min.
://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.surfcoat.2015.12.058
indenter with a nominal angle of 65.3° and a nominal radius curvature of 20 nm at a normal load of 100 mN and a sliding velocity of 1mm·s−1. A dwell time of 5 swas used at themaximum load, and a period of 60 s was maintained at 90% of the loaded condition for thermal drift correction. A minimum of at least 10 tests was carried out on each samples investigated. The indentations were conducted by the load-control mode, whereby the load was applied and then released after the set peak load. Load–displacement curves were obtained by the Oliver and Pharr method [17]. From the load–penetration curves, elastic and plastic deformation energies, surface hardness (H), and Young's modulus (E) were calculated using integrated software.

sections.heading: 2.5.2. Scratch test
sections.text: Scratch tests of the coating were performed at room temperature with the Nanoindenter XP (CSM Instruments) using a Rockwell spherical diamond tip with a radius of 100 mm. The scratch tests were performed by increasing the load from 30 mN to 10 N (load rate: 0.5 N·s−1) with a table speed of 6 mm·min−1 over a distance of 2 mm. The adhesion of the coatings to the substrates was assessed based on changes of the frictional force recordedduring themeasurement process and confirmed by optical micrographs.

sections.heading: 3.1. Elaboration and characterization of nano-HAP coatings
3.1.1. Impact of the experimental parameters
sections.text:
To produce the most suitable nano-HAP coating, the effect of two experimental deposition parameters was explored. First, the effect of
the variation of the potential was investigated as shown in Fig. 2 that presents nano-HAP coatings obtained by EPD during ten minutes at 5 V, 10 V, 15 V and 20 V. According to Corni et al. [8], the potential value applied during the process is linked to the migration force that set in motion the particles in the suspension.
Fig. 2 indicates that the substrate remains almost bare when the deposition is carried out at 5 V. This observation suggests that at to low potential the particles in the suspension cannot migrate properly, i.e. fast enough to reach the substrate to produce a homogeneous coating [18]. The coating deposited at 15 V is highly heterogeneous with some holes and cracked areas, whereas coatings deposited at 10 V and 20 V appear visually homogeneous. However, some closer observations of these samples carried out by SEM reveal that the coatings deposited at 15 V and 20 V are highly cracked whereas the coating deposited at 10 V is confirmed to be the most homogeneous one (Fig. 3). These observations indicate that the two potentials 15 V and 20 V do not lead to an adequate agglomeration at the surface of the substrate, resulting in the formation of several cracks [19]. Thus, it is obvious that the potential of 10 V is the most suitable one. Moreover, the inset SEM images at higher magnification show that the coatings were formed by agglomeration of nano-sized particles with some noticeable porosity due to the size dispersion of the particles [20].
In the next step, the selected voltage (10 V) was used to test the effect of various deposition times: 5 min, 10 min, 15 min and 20 min. The four resulting coatings are shown in Figs. 4 and 5. After 5min deposition time (Figs. 4a and 5a), it appears that this time is too low to yield a coating that properly covers the surface [8]. After 10 min (Figs. 4b and 5b), a coating with maximum homogeneous surface was obtained, whereas after 15 min (Figs. 4c and 5c) and 20 min (Figs. 4d and 5d) the samples present some cracks and some uncovered areas. These observations can be attributed to an excessive agglomeration of the particles at the surface of the substrate that progressively increases the surface electrical resistance [18].
According to these results, the best electrophoretic deposition conditions were established to be at 10 V for 10 min that define then our best nano-HAP coating.

sections.heading: 3.1.2. Physico-chemical and structural study
sections.text:
Characterization of the nano-HAP coating synthesized by EPD at 10 V during 10min was carried out by EDXS and XRD (Fig. 6), revealing a representative atomic ratio (Ca/P = 1.66) and an apparent XRD pattern of hydroxyapatite (PDF file # 09-0432). This confirms that the chemical and phase compositions of the HAP nano-powder are being conserved during the electrophoretic deposition process. Subsequently, our best coating was heat-treated, following the specific thermal treatment under controlled atmosphere at 1000 °C previously developed [13]. Looking at the SEM images of Fig. 7, it is apparent that this thermal treatment promotes generation of several small surface cracks caused by evaporation of solvent trapped within the coating [21]. The
oating obtained by EPD at 10 V in 10 min. after thermal treatment.
corresponding EDXS spectrum (Fig. 8, left) indicates that the chemical composition of the coating is not modified by the thermal treatment since the Ca/P atomic ratio remains stable, corresponding to that of hydroxyapatite (Ca/P = 1.66). The XRD pattern (Fig. 8, right) presents slight differences after the thermal treatment. Whereas hydroxyapatite is still the only calcium phosphate phase present, the diffraction peaks are narrower than those previously obtained, indicating enhancement of the crystallinity of the coating [21]. The signal obtained from the titanium alloy substrate is less pronounced, probably owing to the increase of the density of the coating during thermal treatment.

sections.heading: 3.2. Mechanical tests
sections.text:
Fig. 9 shows the evolution of the normal force as a function of the penetration depth obtained by nanoindentation at the surface of the nano-HAP coating before and after the thermal treatment. In both cases, the plastic energy is much higher than the elastic energy, which indicates the plastic behaviour of the coatings. The maximum depth of penetration (hmax) is about 13 μm before the thermal treatment, reduced to about 2.5 μm after the thermal treatment. These results are related to an increase of the surface hardness from H = 5.4 to 153.5 MPa, and of the Young's modulus of the coating from E = 5.2 to 19 GPa, suggesting that the coating became more compact and less porous. An increase of the Young's modulus is considered essential to reduce the stiffness mismatch between the metallic implant and the supporting bone (E≈20 GPa) [22]. Indeed, this mechanical parameter is a key factor to transfer the adequate mechanical stress from the implant to the surrounding bone [23].
Fig. 10 presents the scratch tests results obtained on the nano-HAP coating before and after the thermal treatment under controlled atmosphere. Before the thermal treatment (Fig. 10a), the friction force suddenly increases for a critical load of Lc=3.8N that corresponds to the total removal of the coating as observed by the optical micrograph. After the thermal treatment (Fig. 10b), the friction–load curve obtained is drastically different, showing four stages and three critical loads, confirming that the spallation of the coating occurs gradually.
The first critical load Lc1 = 3.3 N reveals the start of the coating cracking associated with its cohesive limit. The second critical load Lc2 = 6.0 N indicates the start of the coating spallation linked to its adhesive limit as confirmed by the optical micrograph. The total removal of the coating is then observed at Lc3 = 7.9 N. The increase of the critical load associated with the adhesive limit clearly demonstrates that the thermal treatment improves the coating adhesion to the Ti6Al4V substrate. This improvement of the mechanical properties of
Please cite this article as: R. Drevet, et al., Surf. Coat. Technol. (2015), http
the implant is essential for orthopaedic surgery that involves high mechanical stress during the implantation time [4,24].

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text: This work reports on electrophoretic deposition as an innovative process to produce a homogeneous nano-HAP coating on the prosthetic titanium alloy surface. The so-obtained implant material has been thermally treated in controlled atmosphere to confer appropriate mechanical properties to the coating that are close to that of the substituted bone. Hence, this work has highlighted the synthesis of a suitable biomaterial with interesting properties for orthopaedic surgery. Biocompatibility studies of this new implant design are in progress to assess its clinical and industrial potentials.
